meta.content: COVID-19 Updates March 30, 2020 Good Afternoon Pentucket Families, Below are links for a letter from the Commissioner of the Massachusetts Department of Elementary and Secondary Education (DESE), Jeff Riley. The Commissioner has asked that we share this letter with all families as it highlight...

DOCS_modelChunk = [{"ty":"is","ibi":1,"s":"COVID-19 Updates

March 30, 2020
Good Afternoon Pentucket Families,

Below are links for a letter from the Commissioner of the Massachusetts Department of Elementary and Secondary Education (DESE), Jeff Riley. The Commissioner has asked that we share this letter with all families as it highlights the guidelines and recommendations DESE has made for public schools during the time we are out.

Letter to Families (English Version)

Letter to Families (Spanish Version)

Be well!
~ Dr. B.

March 25, 2020:
Dear Pentucket Family,

Governor Charlie Baker just announced that schools are to be closed until Monday, May 4th. Knowing that this was an extended amount of time away from the physical classroom, the Governor and the Commissioner of Education, Jeff Riley, stated that guidelines will be sent to districts tomorrow morning describing how we are to proceed. The Commissioner also stated that it is expected that school districts will implement these guidelines in early April. 

We all know that COVID-19 has had a significant impact on all of our lives. While the health and safety of our children and entire community needs to be our first priority, continuing to keep our children engaged in the learning process is essential to their future and that of our community. I believe that our school district is well-positioned to be able to continue to support our children through these challenging times. That being the case, I also want to be clear that nothing we put in place will be able to replace the learning that takes place inside a physical classroom. What I do know is that during these next five weeks, we will see significant increases in innovation when it comes to our students and teachers.

Your school administrators and teachers will be reaching out to you with more specifics once we receive those guidelines and we have had a chance to determine how we will best be able to support our children.

Stay safe!
~ Dr. B.

March 15, 2020:
PRSD Families COVID-19 Letter
March 15, 2020

Good Evening Pentucket Families,

The shifts that have occured in the past few days are unprecedented. In just education, we
have seen some schools close for a couple weeks and others through April. There are
numerous items and scenarios to consider, and we have been working constantly to stay
informed on the numerous variables. On Thursday, March 12, 2020, the PRSD School
Committee met and I updated them on multiple items related to our response to the COVID 19
viral outbreak. Additionally, the Commissioner of Education held a conference call at 8:30 AM
on Friday, March 13, 2020 where a few lingering questions were addressed, however several
issues still remain unanswered as this is simply unprecedented.

As you were notified on Friday, March 13, 2020 - Pentucket Schools will be closed for two
weeks from Monday, March 16, 2020 through Friday, March 27, 2020. Area Superintendents
from over 25 Northshore districts made this decision in unity to protect our communities and
slow the spread of the COVID 19 virus. We are continuing to monitor the situation and we are in
communication constantly with local and state officials. We are constantly reassessing the
situation, and will make adjustments as needed using the information from our health officials
and government officials as our foundation. As you are aware, this could mean that we return
earlier than March 27th, or it could mean that we remain out longer.

Slowing the Spread - A Collective Effort

There is no question that the closure of schools and daycares creates incredible disruptions and
inconveniences on families. We want you to understand that the closures are not to just
thoroughly clean the buildings, but rather to assist with social distancing to slow the progression
of the virus. We need families help with this. While the majority of our students are not in the
high risk group because of their age, some of our students and staff are considered vulnerable

DOCS_modelChunk = [{"ty":"is","ibi":4059,"s":"risk. Our collective response is what is needed. While we obviously cannot mandate this, we
would encourage families to refrain from play dates, gatherings of friends and other typical
social activities. If children are gathering and hanging out during this closure, it does not help
slow the possible spread of COVID-19 and these closures will be much longer. I know this will
be challenging but it is important.

Additionally, it is very important to keep your social circles small. Whenever there is a potential
case of COVID-19 in Massachusetts, the public health nurse in that city or town completes what
is called contact tracing. The tracing process requires gathering information about every person
the suspected case has come in close contact (within 6 feet) with. By keeping our social circles
small, we can greatly enhance the effectiveness of that tracing and containment of COVID-19.
There is a helpful article on this subject titled This Is Not a Snowday

How do we make our decisions during this unprecedented time?

We have been routinely communicating with the following and abiding by all recommendations
from the CDC and Local and State officials:
 Local and state Health Agents
 Mass Public Health
 DESE/Commissioner
 Superintendents across the region and state
 District Physician

Decisions to close school and how/when does it get made up:
Decisions to close school have been left to local officials to make. At the present time, we have
no known, confirmed or even presumed cases of COVID 19 in West Newbury, Groveland or
Merrimac. While there are some situations where people have been asked to self-quarantine
due to possible exposure, none have displayed symptoms, and they are being monitored by
local health officials.

The MA Dept. of Elementary and Secondary Education (DESE) has altered the requirements to
make up school days missed due to this situation. We will only be required to make up days up
to the previously scheduled 185 days. Currently, we are scheduled to end school on Friday,
June 19th. Our 185th day would be Wednesday, June 24th. Each missed day of school would
be added on in June - but only up to Wednesday, June 24th. We will not exceed that date
unless some other guidance or situation is presented. At this time, in the event of a multiple
week closure, school would still end on June 24th and no later.

We have closed School - but for how long?

 Multi Day closings (2 weeks or less)
 Occurring to prevent community spread.
 Three of these days would be made up in June.
 We would seek to use some form of Learn at Home to keep students engaged
and connected but it would not replace a normal school day.
 There would be no expectation that students are sitting at a computer all day and
following any sort of full schedule from home. - see expectations for learning
Below.
 Communication from your childs teachers is expected for portions of these days
but these are not full virtual days of school.
 Multi week closings (More than 2 weeks)
 May occur per directive of state officials, or locally based on the information we
receive from our Local Health Agents.
 Three of these days would be made up in June but state officials may make
further calendar requirements.
 We are planning to use some form of Learn at Home to keep students engaged
and connected but it would not replace a normal school day.
 There would be no expectation that students are sitting at a computer all day and
following any sort of full schedule from home.- see expectations for learning
Below.
 Communication from your childs teachers is expected for portions of these days
but these are not full virtual days of school.

Other measures to protect our students and staff while we continue to operate:

 Immediately , as of March 13, 2020 I have ordered following:
 When school resumes, no volunteers or outside visitors are allowed inside the
school buildings.
 All school related travel by students and staff is postponed/suspended until

DOCS_modelChunk = [{"ty":"is","ibi":8063,"s":"further notice including in-state field trips and out of state field trips.
 All after school events and extra curricular activities by students and staff are
postponed/suspended until further notice. This includes clubs, plays, musicals,
intramurals, etc.
 The 8th grade Washington DC trip has not been officially cancelled or postponed
at this time, however we are negotiating with the vendor for a fair treatment to our
families in the likely scenario that we will not be able to travel on May 5th. We will
update impacted families in the coming days.
 No outside vendors or groups, such as rentals and recreation programs will be
allowed to utilize any of the school buildings in all three towns.
 Additionally - the MIAA has suspended all HS spring sports until the end of March and
they will re-assess the start of the season in the coming weeks. This also means that
there should not be any Captains Practices organized by students.

During our closures - will there be Virtual Learning? What can I expect for learning?

It is important to understand that neither our school district, nor all of our families are set up for
true virtual learning. As I mentioned previously, many college professors are scrambling trying
to figure out how to deliver their curriculum electronically, and they are working with a
demographic that is completely ready to learn digitally.

Our initial approach will be to keep students engaged in the learning process by implementing a
plan to have students Learning From Home. This will differ from the Alternative Learning Days
that we have used for the past 2 years during inclement weather.

The priorities of a Learn From Home model will be:

#1 Maintaining a connection to students (phone calls, email, google hangout, etc.)
#2 Keeping students engaged in learning with activities

These are not Virtual School Days , but rather opportunities to learn from home and stay
engaged. There will be activities and learning opportunities but not assignments and
grades . Students should not be expected to hand in assignments for grades, however teachers
may be able to provide feedback for activities that students are engaged with.

Other than a few high school classes, like AP classes at the High School level, it is unlikely that
our curriculum and content could be replicated in the manner it is delivered in school. However
the College Board has issued a statement that will permit some AP testing flexibility if that is
needed. Keeping that in mind, however, during an extended closure we can continue to
communicate with our students and families. We are coordinating with our teachers about the
tools such as phone calls, email, google classroom, google hangouts for conferencing calling,
etc. that could be utilized to maintain this connection and engagement. Staff would be providing
learning activities that could be worked on over multiple days, including reading text or watching
videos with follow up discussions, be it online or through google hangouts. For the most part -
these would be ungraded but with the expectation that students maintain their skills and
connections. It may not all need to be done via technology either and some hard copies of
materials would be made available.

Again, this is not to replace the instruction teachers normally do - but rather keep a connection
with students and keep them engaged. Work from these days would not be counted negatively
against student grades or measured performance but rather focused on the two focus points
listed above. This is about keeping students engaged and maintaining communication. We will
offer the following to help support this:

Chromebooks

 For those who do not have technology at their homes, we have made arrangements for
a chromebook pick up that will take place this Tuesday through Thursday (if we are
allowed to stay open). If your family does not have a device or has limited access
because of singular devices, this is an option for you. We have also added Bark as a

DOCS_modelChunk = [{"ty":"is","ibi":12083,"s":"cyber security feature. Please use this link to make a request and arrange for pick up.
We have limited devices so we ask that you only request this if you feel it is necessary.
https://forms.gle/B86BzFDPUXhNmVDc9

The following supports will also be available:

 Our Mental Health staff (counselors and psychologists) will be available via, phone or
google hangout or through email to connect with students or families. They have
resources and links available to help students of all ages to process the current situation.
 Special Education Service Providers will also be able to consult with parents and
students providing guidance and support via, phone or google hangout or through email.
 School Nurses will be available for communication about health concerns. If you have
medication stored in school that your child needs access to, please communicate with
your childs principal and the school nurse so arrangements can be made for access to
That.

Food Security

 We want to support families who may have a challenging time providing enough food for
their children during these unexpected closures. While the federal school lunch and
breakfast program has offered up some flexibility programs for districts to feed families,
none of these flexibility accomodations apply to the Pentucket Schools at this time.
Therefore, we are coordinating with Our Neighbors Table - our regional food security
network which covers all three towns. This organization is prepared to help and offers
pick up locations/markets in Amesbury and Newburyport and we will continue to work
with them so they may sustain an operation in Merrimac. You can be a resident in any of
the three towns to access this and you do not need to be qualified for free and reduced
lunch. They are a No Questions Asked organization. If you need assistance, please
access this great organization.
https://www.ourneighborstable.org/programs--services.html

Internet Accessibility

 While any school work and assignments are completely optional and designed to simply
maintain connections and engagement, we recognize that some of our families may not
have enough devices or home based internet that would permit multiple devices being
connected. Comcast is also stepping up to support you. Below is information about
quickly gaining high speed internet access at your home at an extremely reduced price.
 From Comcast - A hallmark of this program has been our flexibility in adjusting Internet
Essentials to meet the needs of low-income residents in our footprint. So, effective Monday, we
are putting in place two substantial program enhancements to help these families deal with this
Crisis.
1. We will make it even easier for low-income families who live in a Comcast service area
to sign up by offering new customers 60 days of complimentary Internet Essentials
service, which is normally available to all qualified low-income households for
$9.95/month.
2. Also, we are increasing Internet speeds for the Internet Essentials service from 15/2
Mbps to 25/3 Mbps for all new and existing customers, which will be the speed of the
service going forward. In this way, we will ensure that Internet Essentials customers will
be able to use their Internet service for all their increased needs as a result of this health
Crisis.

We want to make it as fast and simple as possible to access this service:

 To receive the increased Internet speeds, existing customers will not need to do anything. The
new speeds will be rolled out nationally over the next few days.
 Well send all new customers a free self-install kit that includes a cable modem with a Wi-Fi
router. There will be no term contract or credit check and no shipping fee.
 To sign up, applicants can simply visit www.internetessentials.com . The accessible website also
includes the option to video chat with customer service agents in American Sign Language.
There are also two dedicated phone numbers 1-855-846-8376 for English and 1-855-765-6995
for Spanish.

DOCS_modelChunk = [{"ty":"is","ibi":16085,"s":"
Before and After School Program

The BASP will be closed while the School District is closed. Three of these days will be made
up in June. For any days beyond the 3, families who pay monthly will be credited accordingly to
their normally scheduled days for the following month. For anyone who has paid annually, you
will receive a refund for those days missed. The same will apply if the closure is extended.

Cleaning the School Buildings

We will utilize this time to complete an enhanced cleaning of our buildings and seek to keep the
buildings clean by restricting access. We will continue communication with local and state health
officials and re-assess the situation in the days prior to March 27, 2020 to decide if the closure
will be extended. Our enhanced cleaning includes the use of a fogging machine, and wiping
down high use surfaces to disinfect.

How can our family help others?

Many of you have already asked, how can we help others who may be more impacted by these
changes. Our communitys generosity and support for one another will be a great comfort to
many. First and foremost, the most helpful thing your family can do is to understand that the
schools are closed to slow the spread of the virus by eliminating the large numbers of people
gathering in a space daily. Please avoid having large numbers of children gathering outside of
school, as that defeats the purpose and may only lengthen the time we need to keep schools
Closed.

For those looking to support others, making monetary donations to Our Neighbors Table - the
Regional Food Security Network - may be one of the most helpful and generous things you can
do. Collections of food items, etc. - while normally are very welcomed - present an added
challenge for this organization at this time. To donate funds so they can purchase the necessary
foods, please use this link below.

https://www.ourneighborstable.org/give.html

Communicating with us

Central Services will maintain operations for the district and remain open with limited staffing
levels unless we are directed this is no longer possible. All school offices will be closed. Email is
likely the best means of communicating. You can always call Central Services at 978.363.2280
if you need to, but again, understand that we may not have the phone lines manned often during
the closing.

We will be communicating regularly through email with Campus, using Twitter @PentucketRSD,
and posting information to the PRSD website https://www.prsd.org/

Thank you!

I want to thank all of you for your patience and support. We will continue to keep you updated
and please remember that the purpose of the school closures is to decrease the spread of the
virus by limiting person to person interactions. Please do your part to help with this. The sooner
the spread slows, the sooner we will be back to school and our normal routines.
 

March 13, 2020, 3:13 PM:

OFFICIAL PRESS RELEASE
PRESS RELEASE:
North Shore Schools to Close Starting Monday Schools to Close through at Least
March 27 
The North Shore area superintendents have collaborated to make a timely and unified
decision about school closure that they feel is in the best interests of their faculty, staff,
students, and families. This decision was made after significant conversations among
school leaders, local public health officials, and state officials. State officials have today
urged that municipalities should make decisions based on their local circumstances,
and given the rapidly changing COVID-19 crisis, which the World Health Organization
has this week labeled a global pandemic.

 The following districts have mutually decided to close schools through at least March 27:
1. Amesbury Public Schools
2. Beverly Public Schools
3. Chelsea Public Schools
4. Danvers Public Schools
5. Essex North Shore Agricultural and Technical School
6. Everett Public Schools
7. Georgetown Public Schools
8. Gloucester Public Schools
9. Hamilton - Wenham Regional School District

DOCS_modelChunk = [{"ty":"is","ibi":20094,"s":"11. Ipswich Public Schools

21. Rockport Public Schools
22. Saugus Public Schools
23. Swampscott Public Schools

 Leadership for all 28 school districts have decided to close their school facilities
beginning on Monday, March 16 through Friday, March 27. School district leadership
will continue to re-evaluate the situation on a day-by-day basis.

 The school leaders held a conference call today after a lengthy call with the Department
of Elementary and Secondary Education and the Massachusetts Department of Public
Health. During that call, no determination was made by the state on widespread school
closure. The superintendents in this region have consulted with health experts and their
own municipal public health agents in reaching a decision that, while difficult, is in the
interests of the safety and wellbeing of their communities, which is paramount at all
times.
 
The decision to collectively close schools on the North Shore area has been made after
significant consideration and in an effort to proactively address the evolving novel
coronavirus (COVID-19) situation.
 
The Department of Secondary and Elementary Education (DESE) is advising districts
throughout the state this morning to cancel or reschedule gatherings of 250 people or
more and to limit instances where students, faculty, and staff are closer than 6 feet
away from each other. While DESE is not explicitly advising districts close at this time,
due to the concerns regarding the spread of this virus among crowds, area
superintendents feel it is prudent to close their facilities temporarily. District leaders
additionally encourage students and staff to avoid being in large crowds of
people in order to further prevent the spread of the virus.
 
Massachusetts school districts have been informed that no district will have to go past
June 30 and that school districts will not have to go beyond their planned 185th day of
school, regardless of the COVID-19 situation.
 
Each district will additionally provide updated information through their websites
and individual communication channels to their communities as more
information becomes available.
 
The following is a statement from the superintendents in the 28 districts:
The health and wellbeing of our students, faculty, and staff are of the utmost
importance to us all on the North Shore, and as a result, weve collectively decided to
close our school facilities for the next two weeks. This is being done in an effort to
proactively address the evolving COVID-19 situation. We have each been in close
communication for months now with our local and state health officials to ensure were
following their recommendations for preventing the spread of this virus.
 
We believe by closing our facilities for this period of time, we will have a positive impact
on preventing the spread of this virus and promoting public health and safety by
creating a united response to this situation.
 
Symptoms of the virus include fever, cough, and shortness of breath, and can appear
between two and 14 days after exposure, according to the Centers for Disease Control
and Prevention (CDC). Anyone who experiences symptoms and believes they may
have the virus is advised to contact their health care provider. For more information
from the CDC for those who may have the virus, click here .
 
The North Shore superintendents also wish to encourage students and staff to follow

DOCS_modelChunk = [{"ty":"is","ibi":24158,"s":"recommended preventative steps from the DPH:
 
 Practice good hand hygiene! Wash your hands often with soap and water for at
least 20 seconds including under your fingernails. Alcohol-based hand sanitizer
(at least 60% alcohol content) can be used when soap and water are not
available.
 Keep your hands away from your face.
 Cover your nose and mouth when sneezing and coughing with a tissue and
discard it immediately. Cough into the sleeve over your elbow instead of your
hand. Wash your hands often when coughing and sneezing.
 Stay away from people who are sick and stay home when you are sick.
For more information, visit the DPH website by clicking here and the CDCs website by
clicking here .

March 13, 2020, 1:26 PM:
Dear Pentucket Community,
Pentucket, along with several North Shore school districts, has decided to close its facilities beginning Monday, March 16 through Friday, March 27 in an effort to reduce the risk of exposure to the novel coronavirus (COVID-19) to our school community. This decision comes after significant consideration and as we await additional guidance, specific procedures, and information from state and federal officials. We will provide you all with updated information as it becomes available. 
The health and well-being of our students, faculty and staff is our primary concern at all times. 
While we realize and acknowledge that we are not setup for virtual learning, we value the concept of keeping children engaged and actively learning. Consequently, we hope to post (on school websites or possibly from teachers via email) some ideas on optional activities (e.g. reading, writing, games, etc.) that children can be doing while we are out of the buildings. It is not the intent to deliver the curriculum through these methods or to grade anything that children do. All of these activities are optional and designed to stimulate their minds and keep them engaged in the learning process.
This virus has caused a great deal of concern internationally, and our district is here to support our students, faculty, and staff. I would encourage you to have honest conversations with your children about what is happening with the coronavirus as this can be a very stressful and anxious topic for them given all of the media and social media attention that they see without any explanation. As such, here are several resources that you may find helpful: 
How to Talk to Children about the Coronavirus: Click Here
Talking to Teen/Tweens about Coronavirus: Click Here
Here is a pamphlet from the article: Click Here
Thank you for your patience and cooperation as we navigate this complex, evolving situation.
~ Dr. B.



March 11, 2020:

I would like to provide residents with the latest information regarding the novel coronavirus (COVID-19) as federal and state officials continue to monitor the virus internationally.

There are currently 92 confirmed or presumptive positive cases of COVID-19 in Massachusetts, according to the Massachusetts Department of Public Health (DPH), and Gov. Charlie Baker declared a state of emergency on March 10. There are currently no confirmed or presumptive cases of COVID-19 in Groveland, West Newbury, or Merrimac at this time. There are currently no confirmed or presumptive cases of COVID-19 in Groveland, Merrimac or West Newbury at this time. Health officials report that the risk of contracting the virus in Massachusetts remains "low."

School district officials are having daily conversations with the health agents for the towns in the district to make sure we are all following the same protocols and procedures. We're continuing to monitor the situation and will continue to share information with the community as it becomes available.

Pentucket District schools are open and functioning on their normal schedules. 

I will be speaking with other Massachusetts superintendents and the Commissioner from the Massachusetts Department of Elementary and Secondary Education tomorrow afternoon. Further updates and guidelines are expected at that time.

DOCS_modelChunk = [{"ty":"is","ibi":28212,"s":"
The School District Committee will be meeting Thursday, March 12 at 5:30 p.m. to further discuss additional steps to take.

The Massachusetts Interscholastic Athletic Association (MIAA) will be moving forward with its tournaments as well and has indicated that sporting events scheduled through March 15 will proceed as scheduled. 

All local actions are being undertaken in accordance with the latest guidelines from the Massachusetts Department of Public Health and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). This includes CDC guidance for school administrators.

The COVID-19 situation is very fluid, and new information and guidelines are being posted by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) on a regular basis. The CDC offers the following guidance for how COVID-19 spreads. The virus is believed to spread mainly from person-to-person, between people who are in close contact with one another (within about 6 feet) and through respiratory droplets produced when an infected person coughs or sneezes. It may also be possible that a person can get COVID-19 by touching a surface or object that has the virus on it and then touching their own mouth, nose, or possibly their eyes, but this is not thought to be the main way the virus spreads.

The Department of Elementary and Secondary Education has determined that it will not count absenteeism from early March onward, and that school districts will not have to extend the school year beyond its planned end dates as a result of the coronavirus. Pentucket School District officials will continue to monitor the situation and proceed in a way that both minimizes the disruption to students learning while ensuring the wellness of the school community.

As always, if anyone displays symptoms of COVID-19, including a fever, cough or shortness of breath, they should not come to work or school and they are advised to contact their primary care physician. 

The DPH recommends that residents continue with good hygiene practices including:
Practice good hand hygiene! Wash your hands often with soap and water for at least 20 seconds including under your fingernails. Alcohol-based hand sanitizer (at least 60% alcohol content) can be used when soap and water are not available.
Keep your hands away from your face.
Cover your nose and mouth when sneezing and coughing with a tissue and discard it immediately. Cough into the sleeve over your elbow instead of your hand. Wash your hands often when coughing and sneezing.
Stay away from people who are sick and stay home when you are sick.

For more information, visit the DPH website by clicking here and the CDCs website by clicking here.

Sincerely,

~ Dr. B.


March 4, 2020:

COVID-19 Update

4 March 2020

Dear Pentucket Regional School District Community,

We are reaching out to provide information about the respiratory disease, COVID-19, or the coronavirus.
According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), there are 80 cases of the virus that
have been confirmed or are presumed positive in the United States, as well as 48 cases among persons
repatriated to the United States from the Diamond Princess Cruise Ship and from Wuhan, China.

At this time, exposure risk remains low for individuals who have remained in the U.S. and who have
not traveled abroad to countries where the virus has spread, and there are no confirmed or suspected
cases in Groveland, Merrimac or West Newbury.

There is currently one confirmed case and one "presumptive positive" case of coronavirus in Massachusetts,
according to the Massachusetts Department of Public Health (DPH).

Pentucket School District is monitoring the COVID-19 situation nationwide. The district has also been
conducting regular disinfecting and cleaning efforts of all schools in the district, as is normal during the flu
Season.

The district is aware that members of the Pentucket Towns may have traveled during February break and
possibly on the weekends. We would like the community to know that we will offer alternative learning

DOCS_modelChunk = [{"ty":"is","ibi":32263,"s":"days and the use of virtual classroom technologies for those families that traveled in the CDC identified
areas and are following the CDC recommendations. Please contact your school's principal if this applies to
your family and your school's principal can help set that up for your student(s).

Any students who, by advice of the CDC, self-quarantine and do not report to school will not be held
accountable for days missed and given every opportunity to continue and keep up with their studies in effort
to ensure minimal or zero disruption in their educational progress.

Parents and guardians are reminded that, in an effort to prevent the spread of infectious diseases such as the
flu, respiratory viruses and gastrointestinal illnesses, students need to be free from fever, vomiting or
diarrhea for 24 hours before returning to school if they have been sick, and are advised to stay home and not
go to school if they are presenting any of those symptoms.

In an effort to prevent the spread of flu, colds and other respiratory illnesses, residents are recommended to
take the following measures from DPH:
 Wash your hands often with soap and water for at least 20 seconds, if unable to wash, use
alcohol-based hand sanitizers
 Avoiding touching your eyes, nose, and mouth
 Cover your coughs or sneezes with a tissue or sleeve (not with your hands)
 Stay away from people who are sick and stay home when you are sick
The CDC ( www.cdc.gov ) recognizes that prevention efforts offer the strongest protection from all illnesses
including the coronavirus.

The District will keep you informed of updates or changes as we are advised by our local and state
departments of public health. We hope that this information allows you to make informed choices regarding
you and your familys health and wellness.
Sincerely,
~ Dr. B




February 27, 2020:

Dear Pentucket Community:

With the topic continuing to be a top story in the news, we wanted to update you about COVID-19. 

As federal health officials have continued to monitor the spread of the 2019 Coronavirus (COVID-19), we wish to provide our Pentucket families with some information about the virus. According to the Massachusetts Department of Public Health (DPH) the risk to Massachusetts residents of contracting the virus remains low. 

There has been only one reported case of the virus in the state, and the individual with the virus was returning from Wuhan, China and sought medical care shortly after his arrival in the state. 

The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) did, however, confirm the first possible case of the virus spreading to someone who had not traveled recently in California last night.

The CDC reports symptoms of the virus appear within 2-14 days of exposure, and the DPH reports that symptoms include fever, cough, shortness of breath and, in severe cases, pneumonia. 

It is important for us all to note that the DPH is advising that the flu remains a far more prevalent concern, and as a result, were encouraging our students, faculty, staff, parents and guardians to practice common prevention tips to stay healthy, including frequent hand washing, covering your cough, using hand sanitizer and so on. 

As we do every year for flu season, we are cleaning and disinfecting our classrooms and schools here at Pentucket. In an effort to prevent the spread of infectious diseases such as respiratory viruses and gastrointestinal illnesses, we also wish to remind parents and guardians that students need to be free from fever, vomiting or diarrhea for 24 hours before returning to school if they have been sick. 

For more information on prevention tips to avoid contracting the flu, visit the CDCs website by clicking here. 

As new updates are made available by public health officials that are relevant to our community, we will continue to keep you informed and we hope this information allows you to make informed choices regarding you and your familys health and wellness. 

Sincerely,
